title: What will Uber's end-of-day market capitalization be on 31 December 2020?
possible_answers: More than $50 billion but less than $65 billion
preds: Researched Uber a few days ago and saw the question on here so I might as well add my input. This might be more like 99.5%+ but I'll give it a day or two.
With today's gains, I am capitulating and mitigating the damage that may be done by my past below-consensus expectations.
Would need to fall 14% between now and the end of the year

With 8 sessions left, 52% standard deviation, $80 billion market cap is around -1.6 stdev below current levels, implying around a 6 percent probability of being breached, but adjusting this upward for higher moments (fatter tails on stock prices, higher negative skewness).

Given price declines over the last two days, $80 billion is now about 1 stdev below current price of $51.  Still keeping negative skewness in mind, am adjusting probability of remaining above $80 billion downward to better reflect the likely distribution over the next 11 trading sessions.

Only 13-14 trading sessions left, with 90-day stdev ~52%, below $80 billion implies a -1.1 or -1.2 stdev likelihood.  I adjust for negative skewness (especially given strong positive seasonality) to get 82% for >$80 billion mcap.  Below $65 billion is around a -2.5 stdev event, so only assign a 2% probability.
As of 11 Dec, Uber Technologies Market Cap:93.59B.

20% drop over time as short as 3 weeks happens once in 5yr.
So once in 260 weeks. 3 weeks to go, probability of a drop is 1%.  Most other forecasters are way more skeptical, so I'll adjust for that and say 3%

As of 12/4/2020, UBER's market cap was ~97 billion, and though $80 billion is about 1 standard deviation below current levels for the remaining days in the period, I expect that the distribution of returns through the rest of the year to be negatively skewed, so more of the curve is likely to be above the -1 standard deviation than the normal ~67%.
Stock up another 7% today on this news: https://apple.news/AHO-NjEIYRWm0wbB9K84eYA

I guess some Algo traders just experienced their own true nightmare: for a few minutes, UBER was traded at 72USD in the early European session, and is now back to where it was before - at 50.8 USD, +1,5%
https://www.sg-zertifikate.de/webforms/images/cache/ChartImg/MaxAge1min/USD_UBER/USD_UBER/USD_UBER/CBUL_Bid_Intraday.png
At first I thought it may be due to takeover rumors, then I googled and just found some reports about a 810mn USD federal transportation contract that UBER and LYFT have closed. But that can't be the reason for a 50% jump in stock price. Then I discovered that even TSLA was traded at 750USD for the same few minutes...
https://www.sg-zertifikate.de/webforms/images/cache/ChartImg/MaxAge1min/USD_TSLA/USD_TSLA/USD_TSLA/CBUL_Bid_Intraday.png
The Nasdaq100 indication didn't move much.
Probably a few more selected stocks from the tech sector did the jump (I found it for Apple, Alphabet, Alibaba, Amazon (traded at 4,400USD (!) 8-)) but also Boeing, Cisco, eBay, facebook,...), which may have functioned like a "reverse flash crash" and cause heavy losses to a few brokers and/or FinTechs - maybe it'll be named the "Flash bang of Nov 24,2020". Obviously, what just happened is either the result of a cyberattack, a fat finger trade, or an automated portfolio management/algorithmic trading machine gone wild. Maybe one of the market makers got confused with currencies (operational risk, which should definitely not happen) and placed an iceberg order denominated in EUR but with the USD-value instead - which was then filled immediately. Or some traders, who use trading systems where you leave out the first two digits when entering the price limit for speed's sake, interpreted the figures the wrong way: it's easy to figure out, how an order for TSLA limited at [5][2]7.50USD turns into a 750.00USD order. Or one for UBER at a limit of [5][0].72USD turns into an order at 72.00USD. I'd love to review the full order books and times'n'sales tables now.
I'm pretty sure we'll read about this later.
EDIT: It seems this mirage was a technical issue at Société Générale's internal price aggregation and has not caused any sales on stock exchanges.
It's currently $86 billion. The crowd estimate of only a 5% chance of being more than $80 billion is greatly understating those odds.  https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/UBER/

Current market cap is $87bn. Broadly, the markets tends to move higher over time. They also tend not to move dramatically in the short term, absent unexpected, significant news.  So, what is the likelihood that Uber will decline ~9% (to get below $80bn) over the next 6 weeks? There are no more expected potential catalysts (e.g., an earnings release) for a large move in the stock price, so: a) either some unexpected and highly significant negative news about Uber is released over the next few weeks (~5% chance?) b) or Uber stock price is pulled down as part of a broader market decline (note that given their beta is >1, it wouldn't necessarily take a 9% market decline for Uber's stock price to decline the same).  On the one hand there seems to be an obvious and known catalyst for a downturn as a result of COVID (news of an increase in unemployment claims for the first time in 5 weeks today[1] among a backdrop of rapidly rising cases and deaths), but on the other, the market has been surprisingly resilient through this crisis as a result of Fed intervention and things like vaccine optimism. If I could predict whether or not the market will experience a substantial decline over the next 6 weeks with any accuracy, I'd be running a hedge fund rather than making forecasts here, but let's call the odds of a broader market decline a little worse than 50/50, given the aforementioned bias towards rising markets (~40% chance?) In total, a ~45% chance of a decline in Uber's stock price large enough to drop it from the top bin, and my gut says that's being generous.  Full disclosure: I have long been (and continue to be) very bearish on Uber (Herbert Horan's analysis is very persuasive[2]), but need to learn my lesson - even if you're 100% right about something like this, getting the timing right is more luck than skill - just ask Bill Ackman[3] [1] https://www.marketwatch.com/story/u-s-jobless-claims-jump-31-000-to-742-000-amid-record-coronavirus-surge-11605793299?mod=home-page
[2] http://horanaviation.com/Uber.html
[3] https://www.investopedia.com/news/billionaire-bill-ackman-dumps-herbalife-ending-5year-war-betting-against-it/
Hard not to give >50% to higher than current valuation (per EMH).

UBER reportedly intends to sell its autonomous drive division, no expected buyer mentioned.
If the news was out on Friday already after market close, it propelled UBER to 48.54USD per share at intraday high in the after hours-trading on Nasdaq, which means the market, which means investors probably appreciate selling off an important, yet non-profitable, loss-generating long shot and concentrating on the likely profitable business with driver-based ride-hailing, getting rid of many potential risk of law suit and capital intensive, heavy investment-requiring visionary business for the sake of the mere financial survival of the company.
Short term, this may bring the valuation close to 90bn USD; however, I expect some market turmoil ahead before resolution of the question, which would bring down the Nasdaq and thus tech companies more than proportionately, so that I guess Uber will end up in the range of 65 to 80bn USD, but likely not less than that.
Uber is worth more than $80 billion? Pull the other one.

The people of CA have spoken. Gig workers don't need health care or retirement or steady work. Thus this money losing stock goes thru the roof delivering meals and electric scooters. I should have known better.
Why is this "tech" stock still at $58B? It's got nothing. No capital, no employees, just some cell phone software and a 4 letter word name?

Uber is joining the rest of the market in a downward trending price. While it is currently still above $50 billion market cap, that is likely to decrease in the coming months. Even if stimulus is passed (which continues to be a big if) the controversy brewing for the election, the high unemployment, and the impending earnings reports are all likely to drive prices down in the short term (if not longer).

UBER up 6.7% as of now.
Reports say competitor DiDi
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DiDi
is said to plan an IPO for H1 2021 on the Hongkong Stock exchange - the valuation/market cap of DiDi at initial trading estimated at up to 60bn USD.

Been rangebound between 50bn and 70bn for a while now, with lots of December options held by retail, it is quite unlikely now to break out before the holiday lull. Financial markets are always good for nasty surprises, but the odds are not in favor of a large move, partially because it is anticipated.
Why does the market consider the company worth 62B $? No clue at all.

Market Cap 65B.
Ridiculous. But to remind myself, what this is about. It´s about what the market thinks. It´s not about, what I believe.
The stock price threshold for the $35bn bin is 20.00, which looks remote. On the upside,
Uber dropped equal to the market. When will investors realize that there isn't much there other than losses?

Uber is in dissarray. No longer funding their Autonomous driving at a rate to make it successful. Softbank still funding this turkey as they have too much invested to not do it. $63B cap for a grocery delivery service and a fleet of electric scooters and a bunch of drivers that also work for Lyft. What is not to like? At least you can eat real turkeys.

EDIT:
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-28/uber-said-to-weigh-purchase-of-bmw-daimler-ride-hailing-venture
66bn USD at the time of writing.
Wow, down with the market today, 1.5%, that is a healthy sign, just need 50 more days like this one.

And yet it increases today 2% to $64B market cap. No profits, no business but grocery and food delivery. The airlines have been savaged, the airplane manufactures have been savaged. Auto manufacturers are on the backfoot, yet ride sharing software commands billions in capital....why?
https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2020/09/10/1599758074000/Alphavid--The-airline-sector-is-in-denial-about-its-imminent-collapse/

An interesting analysis of the Uber business model seems to confirm my view and my forecast:
https://mbi-deepdives.com/deep-dive-on-uber/
WOW fully electric "fleet" by 2040, get in now before others do. Given that their only "fleet" to date are a bunch of electric scooters how on earth would anyone care about their statement? Elon will be on Mars in 2040 with self driving Cybertrucks fairing tourists around.

I do not like this question. 
I'd rather determine the number of angles dancing on the head of a pin. At least that has some basis in reality, pins exist.

Currently at 58B, and it´s been +/- 20% around that for months now, in spite of Covid-19 and seeming to be ridiculously overprized to me. It should stay in that corridor, if no miracle happens, but I see a much larger probability on the down side, because every "believer" in this stock should be invested already, and they´re not making profit and probably never will.

It's at $59M now,  need to grow 10%  to  hit $65M+, which may happen on vaccine / crowd immunity news 
Need to drop 20% to to go below $50M, this happens once per 5 years, we have 3 months to go
Reducing projections for higher market cap given cooling market conditions and a higher chance of economic collapse in recent weeks.
Amazingly, Uber down less than 3% today to 33.41USD. Market cap still a silly $58B, but that could change over the coming month.

Uber is a poorly run company, involved in many scandals with an insane loss rate compared to revenues (Seeking Alpha has it 13.67 billion revenues vs -7 billion net income) which is not sustainable, especially with the pandemic. While Covid-19 makes public transport less attractive, total trips are still way down with many people in home office and/or lockdowns. Furthermore, there is an increased preference to use personal transportation, so impressive growth rates or market capture seem unlikely.

You must read about vomit fraud propogated by some Uber drivers. At some point this house of cards will come crashing down. Investors are dream walking.
https://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-biz-uber-vomit-fraud-20180724-story.html
Doesnt´mean I think it´s worth it. The stock market often has more dreams and phantasy in mind than sobering reality...

Market Capitalization of $50 billion would require a drop in share price to around $28.54 (from $31.01 at the moment). It hasn't been this low since May 6th (according to Google). It's natural floor appears to be around $30.00. However, their Price to Sales and Price to Book ratios are quite high at the moment, suggesting their shares are overvalued in the market right now. If the market is rational, share prices will drop. If the market is not, prices could continue to fluctuate slightly or even rise. The market is famously irrational and will continue to inflate itself so long as the federal government props up large companies (such as Uber). Given current sentiments, I think there is a decent chance this occurs.

Looks like its at 54 bln right now. more likely to go down than up because:
1. All the money the fed has pumped into the economy has inflated things a lot, so equities are probably more likely to sell off than to increase a lot by the end of the year. 
2. Uber itself has underperformed equities, by as measured by the nasdaq, which is up 20.18% ytd while uber is down  11.61% ytd. 
3. There seems to be a lot of negative media coverage of Uber.  Right now the crowd is saying 5/43/47/5/0. I'm more bearish than the crowd. I am saying 2/65/30/3/0. Will try to update as things move.

The FT ran an interesting opinion piece on Uber and other "gig economy" companies today that lends some mild support to my bearish hypothesis on Uber. The main argument remains that the Transport Dow is close to its upper cyclical limit (using Bollinger Bands, Keltner Channels or any such metrics) and that Uber's stark underperformance does not bode well for the 4 months ahead. The argument goes: if Uber added zero market cap during a 30% rally, how well will it do when the stock market as a whole invariably gives back some gains? But back to the article. Sarah O’Connor argues that "gig companies are hardly making excess profit by exploiting workers. The reality is stranger than that. They charge customers so little that every big gig company loses money, even with their labour costs compressed. The bigger they get, the more money they lose. The prospectus for Uber’s initial public offering last year showed that in some cases, the company actually pays drivers more than the fare it charges to customers." "The existential question for gig companies is how much demand will remain for their services when they stop being unfeasibly cheap." and "The gig economy wasn’t the future of work after all. In fact, it might not have a future at all." But read it for yourself here: https://www.ft.com/content/11e2e1bf-c1dd-47cc-81b2-2147433ff16d Previous forecast 7/60/33/0/0, change to 8/62/30/0/0. Uber is virtually unchanged since Aug 15th.

Aug 14 Close = 29.99 per share which is about $52.5B market cap for a company whose business model is being challenged by its home state. With about a week left to challenge the court decision, Uber is making noises about leaving the state. It appears the emperor was driving without any clothes on and got caught. This on the heels of Q2's Net Income of (-1,775M) may be making investors wonder when the next shoe will drop and how far the stock will fall.  Ride hailing capital costs born by drivers who have no benefits or security does not make economic sense and floats only on a sea of inverstor provided cash which is fast evaporating.

SFO judge rules that Uber drivers are employees after all. So sad for Uber, now its like a regular company, only with higher costs and falling revenues. Stock is still levitating, but this news should errode value once people try to look at the numbers. Billions wasted on self driving and scootters and god knows what else. Core business is under challenge, can grocery delivery justify a maket cap greater than $50B?

It is extremely worrying that Uber has failed to join in the recent stock market rally, and is especially woeful in comparison to the Dow Transport index. Some downside revision deviating from option-implied probabilities seem in order. I hope the link works, it is Uber vs DJT. https://finance.yahoo.com/chart/%5EDJT#-
I would not pay a third per share of what the market is paying now - and would consider that gambling.
Based on 34 out of 37 analysts say it is a buy the market cap may not change much soon. However, they will next report results Nov. 3rd. It could go down from there. Have to track the news on it.
Could easily be over $65B by the end of the year.

The Q2 results reflect the true worth of the company, the stock price will catch up in Q3. From Bloomberg "In the quarter that ended in June, gross bookings from delivery doubled to $6.96 billion. Mobility, which is predominantly made up of ride-hailing but also includes scooter rentals, declined 75% to $3.05 billion. " "Uber didn’t address the impact that a possible worker reclassification of its drivers could have on operations. Uber was dealt setbacks over the last year in California, where the law is designed to give employee benefits to its workers, and New York, where courts have sided with some drivers. The states represent two of Uber’s largest markets."
Readjusting a bit upward. Pandemic raging but up to 60 billion today.
Current market cap is $56.88 billion and is not likely to fluctuate a large amount.

Perhaps we'll soon see what clothes the emperor is actualy wearing. Be careful, don't trip over the scooters as you head toward the exit.
July 30 = $53B

Perhaps we'll see what clothes the emperor is wearing on Aug 6 when Uber reports more red ink for Q2.
Q1 	Net Income	-2,936.00 Will grocery delivery save them?

$35 bil market cap: $20.23
$50 bil market cap: $28.90
$65 bil market cap: $37.58
$80 bil market cap: $46.24
This week still sitting at $56B for a bunch of underpaid food delivery assets, some scooters, and unemployed drivers. Perhaps this is not valued in US dollars but monopoly money.

Currently as per mid july 2020, the market cap for uber is 56B. Over the year their stock is quite stable  albeit several exuberances. Its unlikely during this pandemic situation that they make any profit as people are still scared to ride sharing. However given that countries are acting on quantitative easing, there’s hot money in the market and there’s chance it could run into their stock, as it helps bring up the stock market in general although theirs per se is not so promising compared to others.
The moment you realize that you've used the wrong metric ...

Currently at 57bn. Risks remain for a negative earnings surprise as social distancing is hurting the number of rides.
https://seekingalpha.com/article/4336108-ubers-2021-profitability-forecast-stake
Crowd consensus, however, is bearish in the extreme, with an implied volatility of just 12% to reach 65 billion theshold.
They overpaid for an also ran. Why do people value this pile of parts so highly? Do you get a free scooter with every meal?
Holding steady at about 50 but how long before people get disenchanted with little returns? Avoiding risk on this one.

June 12 = $55B after a dramatic drop in confidence of the retail traders. Perhaps more will ask themselves just what is the emperor wearing that makes this bet so attractive. What are the assets that can be sold or traded? A pile of scooters?
So close to 50 i dont care, but i guess i would take the under

I don't know what the trigger will be, but this stock cannot levitate forever. General Motors only has a captialization of $41B and actually produces products that last for years. Boeing has a market cap just double of Uber, $114B and make aircraft that work for decades. Both companies have employees and pay living wages and benefits. Uber does none of that.
June 9 it's stubbornly stuck at $64+B. What an amazing amount of capital for an idea and some software. This looks like 1999 all over again.

Current valuation is $64B. It's been growing consistently and is at all time high. Uber is definitely getting into more industries and overall demand for couriers of all sort will only grow. Supply will be easy with so many people loosing jobs. Some of the demand on rides side will also come back. Also, no public transportation in New York.
So the valuation will either be slightly above or slightly below $65B. "Below" range is wider as a percentage.

It has been steady between 53-63 capitalization even when market went down or up. Yes there is exuberance and some predict an 80% drop in the market but stocks remain high on a near term (6 months - Year) significant recovery. Hard to predict.

Sitting comfortably at the upper end of the middle bracket, but slightly underperforming the market now. Therefore allocating higher probability towards 50-65 at the expense of the tails, especially the left.

If the question was for what price I would consider reasonable for the company, I would bei all in with the lowest bin. The market seems to see more there than I do, and in the end it will be the market capitalization on 31 December 2020.

Currently at $61B. Current value is prob some appreciation is best predictor of future value. A lot depends on the virus however there are some tailwinds for Uber which I think give it some more upside from it's current value:
1) Much faster adoption of uber eats because of the pandemic is a plus for uber 
2) Less people want to use public transit and a lot of people can't afford cars especially in cities. Ubers in my experience are cleaner the cabs and are prob going to be used by more people than cabs
3) Uber by virtue of how the app works has built in contact tracing giving them a further leg up on cabs
Throwing in the towel. May 29 = almost $63B market cap. Food delivery is it worth this? What assests does this company have? What patents, what moat surrounding its business model?
It's trending down over time.  35 is crash level, and over 65 is robo car level.  Under 50 best matches recession risk in the fall.
Two rounds of layoffs - and a net increase their capitalization. Clearly, I don't understand this company and its fans.

Flattening the curve from earlier forecast due to high variance in price history. Agree with those who say this is fundamentally overvalued, but:  1) They've been hemorrhaging cash for years, why should that suddenly matter over the next 7 months? 2) Powell says he's not going to run out of ammunition. Equity prices could hold due to general inflation.  3) The EMH is true enough to be useful. The aggregate wisdom of people with skin in the game think this is worth $60b as of today.
Anchoring today's price. EMH. Weighted negative at extreme values due to ongoing Covid risk.

May 15 stable at $56B for a bag of parts. Some pieces of self driving sw, a scooter company, a food delivery service, and a lot of hope. Beyond amazing. I echo the sentiments of @SE_Meyer  and @RRG in our common disbelief in this business.
Despite losing a lot of rides and stock price down still capitalized at 55 billion. Might go down but probably not up. Market is likely to correct lower.

Stock price seems to be sticky considering the large downside risk during a pandemic, which is not set to end any time soon. Ubers business model is especially vulnerable, as transportation demand has disappeared and it always requires a person-to-person interaction so far. Latest news on shrinking Uber's staff was quick and a right decision in order to stop negative cashflows, but it is also telling about the seriousness of the situation. Uber has been one of those ultimate "growth by disruption" stories, but growth is nowhere to be seen. Thus, stock price might end up somewhere around 25 USD at year end, which at the current number of stocks outstanding (1.73B) means a valuation of 43.5B USD. Still some investors will be structurally forced to invest into large cap tech companies, and Uber may be their first choice. 25 USD then may seem reasonable compared to its IPO price.

Uber is going to report a terrible Q2 and a bad Q3.  Trips could be down 80% in Q2 and more than 50% in Q3. While Eats might show growth, it would not be enough (not to mention that Eats has much more competition than the limited competition that Uber faces in Trips).  Uber might have to quit geographies - made acute due to the strange situation of their key shareholders being key shareholders in the top competitors in those geographies.
They are rewarded for investing in LIME and for improving food delivery by 25%, while the main business stalls.
April 6 = $44,8B  Someone bought the guy a new suit and also bought his stock, truely amazing.

April 3= $39.4B 
Finally Mr. Market realizes that the emperor is not only not wearing anything, but he's also not driving anyone anywhere for the next 6 months.
38 now and has been holding there.
March 31 =$48B for what? $4B in cash, a logo, some software and operating licenses? No profit, dwindling revenue and reduced number of drivers. When will the emperor be seen for what he is?
Currently about $48bn, analyst estimates generally fall in the $65-80bn range
March 27 = $47B down in sympathy with the market. No profit, business model under pressure daily, other sharing enterprises screaming in pain. Why does this continue to hold value and for how long?
Uber has $4B in cash and a computed market cap of almost $46B on March 25. I continue to watch in amazement and their market craters worldwide yet their stock soars in a down market.
March 23= $38.6B up 5% in a down market.  My jaw drops again, why?
March 20 moved up to 36.7B, up 4% in a down market, huh? The world is about to live in their homes for weeks on end. What drives this behavior to own unprofitable shares with shrinking sales?
March 19 = 35.32B market cap - who knew it would leap 38% on the day. Someone sees a bargain, not sure I do.

March 18 = 25.546B market cap, down a mere 20% from yesterday. YIKES. 
This dog will NOT hunt and may not recover - even when the virus is history.

March 17 $32B market cap, down 8% today while S&P up 3%.  Business model under extreme pressure worldwide.
Business may recover, but not likely the stock will until can prove profitable.
Decreasing prediction in light of declining stock markets and decline in price of uber specifically.

Have to adjust. Market down 3000 points. Capitalization is at 34.8 today. Things should pick-up by November but we could be in recession. 53% chance says Bloomberg and except a couple times bear markets are usually followed by recession.

March 16 cap = $34.3B down 11% from previous close. Market says this business model will be severly impacted for the duration of the covid-19 epidemic. Recovery to the business is possible, but the stock may be permanently damaged as the glow fades from the business model.

March 12 close = $38.975B. 
Bouncing back may be hard with markedly fewer transactions for the next few quarters.
March 12 =$40.6B and still falling. Not clear that this business model will thrive in this climate of fear.

March 10 cap=$45.5 and still eroding due to poor market and reduced overall travel and working from home.
Chances of turning a profit this year continue to be elusive.

I expect a reemergence of the corona virus in the winter which will hit this ride sharing company badly. In fact, this year might be poor for this company because of this virus, i expect it to be under 30 billion market cap by then. Even with a corona vaccine, panic and fear will cause this company to take longer to bounce back than other public transportation modes such as airplanes and cruise ships. 
Lower annualized gas prices may help their bottom line though. But no growth, or even drops, in monthly users rates will cast doubts on their future.

March 9 cap = $48.5B more downward pressure likely as travel is stalled and work from home and events cancelled.  Another 10% down and your still in the second bucket, even 20% down and your still in the second bucket, but just barely. The stock market will recover some day, but this model has not been tested before in a recession.
54 billion now. Significant problems with governments deeming drivers as employees and launching new services.

Today's cap is $55.5B for a company not making a profit that depends on contract workers to provide the rolling stock and the labor. As the virus grabs more and more real estate world-wide much of the rolling stock may stop. Fewer travelers need a lift to the airport, many people working from home for extended periods. Large events cancelled or postponed. Q1/Q2 results not likely to be pretty. The ecomony will recover, but will this stock?
March 2 Uber cap at $55.6B and still losing money. But a 10% drop would still keep in the middle bucket.
Feb 28, Uber up in brief relief rally.  Today's market cap is just above $58B squarely in the middle bucket.

Feb 27, Uber is down 20% from peak....who knew? Today's market cap is just above $55.7B. 
Turns out "sharing" is not as much fun with virus in the air. Another 10% drop and we're at the bottom of the middle bucket. Look out below.
Continued market turmoil reduced Uber cap Feb 26 to about $60B, my guess is we'll be here most of the year.

Market in free fall for two days and Uber market cap now just above $61.6B Feb 25 close. 
People may be reluctant to take transport during lock downs and self quarentine. Global economy slows dramatically in Q1, fewer ala carte rides.

What will Uber's end-of-day market capitalization be on 31 December 2020?
FInally hit an air pocket, Feb 21 =$69.9B unlikely to scream skyward in the near future.
Resilient on a rather down day overall.
Uber is doing great. I don't see the price moving a lot in one direction or another. They're hovering around the threshold point of 65 billion, so I'll put a bit more weight into where they are.

(today M Cap 64.8bn usd) Increasing competition, regional legislation, unclear intrinsic value, business model issues. higher lower end forecast factors in political and business risk mentioned above, also global downturn risk. optimistic stance for top end justified by increasing global stability, which would need to be in parallel with brand positioning and fortune with legislators. It's competitive advantages at present in established markets is through first mover adv, longevity and awareness, but these historic markers of value are no proof of future success. First mover advantage is short term. It has also come to represent an antagonistic part of globalisation to many in the growing localism/nationalism movements on the traditional "left" and "right" respectively. If i was to be betting, I would go for between 35 and 50, as I believe my deviation from the commonly
68 billion today even with stresses in economy and problems for the company. Shifting upward.
Updating in February. While I'm bearish through the end of the question date, I don't see them losing 20 billion in the next 10 months.

So far as I can see, Uber has no hope of making money with it's present business model.  There is no economy of scale as they grow larger and no obvious way to increase profitability except shrink and raise fares to a level that will support it's operations.  Laying off much of headquarters staff as well. IF self-driving cars come along, then they have a different business model.  I'm not expecting this in 2020 though. Current market cap around 70 billion.  Recent low was around 50 billion.  As earning continues to miss targets, I'd expect valuation to slide and most probably side a lot as reality sets in.  Will it go back to previous low or much lower?  Probably much lower.

(Reuters) - "Uber Technologies Inc on Thursday moved forward by a year its target to achieve a measure of profitability to the fourth quarter of 2020, but the ride-hailing company still expects to lose a total of more than $1 billion this year." Bloomberg mkt cap at $69.7 Feb 8.

It is more probable that company's market cap will go down due to slowing revenue growth and growing penetration on different markets. Moreover, it seems that competition is increasing as well. However, significant decline is less possible because company's management  can arrange different spin-offs, which will support company's valuation in 2020.

Uber might never ever get profitable, which gives a high risk of the market cap going drastically down in the next 11 months (Investors want results someday, and almost a full further year without positive ones would not be good). On the other hand the theoretical chances are immense. Need to follow this one closely. I would at least never invest there myself.

What will Uber's end-of-day market capitalization be on 31 December 2020? Predicting stock market values 12 months out is hard, especially when the company is still loosing money and the business model is still under attack in many places. So I am down shifting to account for an erroding stock market, not normal for an election year.

The company is steadily growing in revenue every quarter. Although mired in all sorts of controversy, the stock price is likely to improve barring any new controversies.  IPOs of decades past (Netflix, Amazon, etc.), that did not turn any significant profits for some years afterward, still registered marked improvements in stock price by the second year.
As I answer this Uber's market cap is 50.3. Even if they lose 20% they would still end the year in the 35-50 range.

After being corrected about the current market cap (thanks @morrelldaniels), I've revised my forecast. I still believe the forecast will trend downward for the same reasons as before (flawed business model, lack of profitable innovations) but the depth of decline is less radical than my initial forecast.
Losing their Medallion in London is reported to take 3% of the top - strengthening position two.

Highest since going public was $42B, and down to $29B as of November 25. The fundamentals of the business are flawed: they lose money with every ride, and their costs will likely rise as their drivers get better protections (see recent California legislation). Their additional businesses (e.g. Uber eats) are not as dominant in their respective fields. There is growing skepticism about investing in tech unicorns in general, which will likely grow worse in 2020 as closer analysis of SoftBank emerges.

What will Uber's end-of-day market capitalization be on 31 December 2020?
Nov 20 2019 Bloomberg says the market cap is $47.8. The market indexes are at all time highs, it's acknowledged that the market is fully or slightly over-valued. What does a 10% correction do to $47.8 it becomes $43B. And a full on market correction of 20% would reduce it to $38B. There is more downside risk that upside potential in this market.

While Uber is almost certainly still overvalued, it appears the marketshare between it and Lyft has stabilized (https://www.statista.com/statistics/910704/market-share-of-rideshare-companies-united-states/). I think the market has priced in what it learned from the WeScam, and hesitation about licensing fees to Waymo. Dara Khosrowshahi is by all accounts a steady manager, not a crazy tech bro. Some chance that if stock languishes for a while and path to profitability continues to improve, we'll see an uptick in a few months. A year is a long time. Will adjust in light of any further events, but at this point a total collapse seems unlikely.

I really like cafebedouin's analysis but it's really just a different way of looking at the forecasting question. December 2020 is a long way away for there is a lot of uncertainty. Like other tech unicorns, I think the major impact on the product side has been had. Unless driving cars are adopted en masse AND Uber is able to capitalize on this, I don't see a lot of options for major growth. The market has largely reached saturation and we're left with Lyft and Uber mainly. I see the rest of their business options (food delivery, scooters, misc. acquisitions) as marginal to their overall value.  What else can they do? Uber a helicopter?   Losing 10 billion from it's market cap is also unlikely.  We can do a lot of analysis, but the outside view is something like: how many companies have lost more than $10 billion in a year? Not many, and it's usually due to some rare event- a natural disaster, government change, etc. I am optimistic on the company's drive to maintain market share. Local government taxes and such may drive demand down slightly, but I don't think we're going to see a resurgence from the Taxi industry.  The services they offer are real. I'm surprised to see so many forecasters making such a pessimistic prediction, and I'd like to know their reasons. Even though we've been on a downward trend, this is a theoretical convergence, not a Ponzi scheme. I think the bracket is super wide and I'm betting 100% it stays in the current range.

Uber on shaky ground. It's a very easily hypeable share though given the technological possibilities it could exploit and the sheer ubiquity and recognition of the brand. It could easily have another spike in 2020 but the real-world foundations of its empire are on shifting sands. Whether that will play out in this time frame I can't be sure - for the moment owning shares long term looks looks more like an exercise in evangalism than economics.

The market can stay crazy longer than you can stay solvent. Given the business model, I'd guess Uber has nowhere to go but down. But, going to hedge the top 3 options and put default on the second from the bottom as a starting point.

Thanks to @cafebedouin for the conversion from Market Cap to price. Makes computation much easier. There about 280 trading days between now and the end of 2020. Since price history is so limited for Uber, I just simulated using S&P500 data from 1970 on. This gave me probabilities of: 
2% 
49% 
42%
5% 
1%.  I think my estimates may be a little optimistic, both given broad market conditions and the rough start Uber has had since IPO. So I will bring everything down a bit.

You could divide these numbers by shares outstanding, i.e., 1.71 billion, to get share price cut-offs of $20.47, $29.24, $38.01 and $46.78 or take today's price differential from $27.01 ($46B market cap) to get ($6.54), $2.23, $11.00, $19.77.  Trend is downward. Probabilities based on last 90 days is something like 41% it stays in the current range, 46% in drops to the lowest option and 13% it increases by $2.23 a share. There's 0% chance it climbs up by $11 or more. I'm going to weigh the lowest option a bit higher.
With such a fewer data points, it is difficult to predict. My analysis shows it is likely to go close or above $35B. But beyond $50B looks have very slim chances.
